subject: Re: [junit] Re: Testing accessors...

messageBody:
> Sirs,

> I think this is important point and it is also possible to be added
> to FAQ:
>
> many programmers writes setters in following style (let's call it
> IBM-style)

That's actually VAJ-style. :)

> void setValue(ValueType newValue)
> {
> value=newValue;
> }
>
> while others preffer to do it in Sun-style:
>
> void setValue(ValueType value)
> {
> this.value=value;
> }
>
> now just imagine that while edditing your code you just pressed
> "del" key in "void setValue(ValueType value)" or made other typing
> mistake and got "void setValue(ValueType vale)" in this case code
> will compile BUT "this.value=value;" will be equivalent
to "this.value=this.value;"
> some times such errors are very hard to find it out... If you have special
> test case for set/get you will find problem within seconds if not
> you will find problem only because other tests are failed...

I agree that typos can make even the simplest code break, but if you want
your tests to catch every typo, then you'll be testing forever. (If you want
to test forever, I won't stop you, unless you're delivering code I'm
responsible for.) There are higher-level approaches to this problem:

* Use macros to generate the source for getX()/setX() methods.

* Stop writing JavaBeans; start writing objects. (I wish more people would do
this. JavaBeans are *not* objects, they are just bags of data. If you're not
using them with a JavaBeans tool, then write real objects!)

* Use a coding convention that eliminates the problem. Some people like
underscores in their fields (I don't, particularly), some people like "a" at
the beginning of a formal parameter name (means "argument"), some people like
to always do an explicit "this." Pick one and go with it. If a coding
convention can avoid the problem, great.

Remember: test until fear turns to boredom. If you're afraid of coding a
method incorrectly, then test it; that includes getX()/setX(). All we're
saying is that many people don't fear methods this simple, so we don't test
them, and we provide our justifications in terms of diminishing returns.

If you spend three hours hunting down a bug because some careless person
wrote "value = value", that's a shame; however, writing 10000 tests, one for
every getX()/setX() method, may not be the most effective use of your time.
As always, YMMV.

> Sorry, for beating the air...

No, this is a good part of the argument that should probably be pointed out.
Thank you for bringing it up.
